results.title: Scotland: the grand tour
results.creator_credit: Alex Riva, Lawrence Riva and Scotia International Television
results.brief_description: Join John Shedden as he narrates a journey around the sights of Scotland. Included on the stop over are: homes of literary figures Robert Burns and Sir Walter Scott, the River Tweed and the popular activities that she offers, St Andrews Golf Course, University of Saint Andrews, the oldest Norman church in Scotland, Earls Hall, Glamis and Blair Castles, battle sights, the Highland Games, Lang Brothers distillery, pubs, Loch Ness, The Trossachs, Pitlochry, Edinburgh, Loch Lomond, Glencoe, Culloden and many more enticements to potential visitors of this lovely country.

results.title: Introducing the atom
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
An overall introduction to the series. Provides a basic explanation of atomic energy. Animated sequences demonstrate the make-up, function, formation and controlled chain reaction. It shows the atomic pile at Los Alamos and the preparation and storage of radio-isotopes at Oak Ridge. Touches on the uses of atomic materials in medical research, agriculture and industry. The film ends with excerpts from President Eisenhower’s speech before the United Nations, emphasising America’s hopes and desires for International control of atomic energy dedicated to human welfare everywhere.

results.title: Schoolboy, sailor, saint
results.creator_credit: Bavo Defurne, Anne Quirynen, Karel Doing, De Filmfabriek, Laika Films and Studio 1
results.brief_description: ‘Schoolboy, Sailor, Saint’ is a compilation of three short films (Saint, Particularly now, In spring and Sailor) from Belguim film maker Bavo Defurne, which explore gay desire, while paying homage to artists such as Jean Genet, Herbert List and Pierre and Gilles. Shot on b/w super-8 and using little sound, ‘Saint’ (1996) is both an indirect tribute to Genet’s homoerotic classic, “Un Chant d’Amore”, and a meditation on the violent death of Saint Sebastian. ‘Particularly now, in Spring’ (1995) is an idealised vision of youth which recounts a seventeen year old boy’s optimistic musings about his future, and the friendships he has forged with the boys at his sports club. The films visual style is influenced by pre-war German art, and by gay Jewish photographer Herbert List. The final film, ‘Sailor’ (1997) is a simply told tale of a boy’s yearning and unrequited love for a sailor, whose adventures at sea are imagined by the wistful boy. Shot on video, ‘Sailor’s‘ vibrant colours and highly stylised backdrops recall the luscious, camp archetypes of gay artists Pierre and Gilles. Cast includes: (Saint) Olaf Nollen, Alex van Stratum (Particularly now, in spring) Olaf Nollen (Sailor) Joram Schurmans, Tom de With.

results.title: Medicine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Shows uses of atomic materials in medical research and diagnosis; illustrates, through a sequence involving a brain tumour, the use of radioactive materials as tracers in the detection and location of disease; and describes atomic research in the treatment of hyperthyroidism, cancer and arteriosclerosis.
